questions.text: A 23-year-old presents with diarrhea, fever, and vomiting. The given bacteria is implicated. Which toll-like receptor binds to the structure of the bacteria marked A?
questions.solution:
The given image and clinical history suggest a typhoid infection. The structure marked A is the flagella of bacteria. Toll-like receptor (TLR) 5 binds to the flagella of bacteria.

Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are transmembrane receptors that have an extracellular domain, that detect infecting pathogens.

  • TLR 1 - Mycobacteria and Gram-negative bacteria  
  • TLR 2 - Mycobacteria and Gram-positive bacteria
  • TLR 3 - Viral RNA 
  • TLR 4 - Gram-negative bacteria
  • TLR 5 - Flagella
  • TLR 9 - Bacterial DNA, some herpes viruses, malarial parasite 

TLRs act through the NF-KB pathway and initiate inflammation.

questions.text: An immunologist is conducting an experiment to understand precipitation reactions. He notes that on adding excessive amount of antigen to a serum sample containing small amount of antibodies, the amount of precipitate formed is less, compared to adding smaller amount of antigen to the same sample. What is this phenomenon called?
questions.solution:
This phenomenon is called post–zone phenomenon because it has excessive antigen in the test system, leading to weak or even absent precipitation. 

Lattice hypothesis explains precipitation reactions. The amount of precipitate formed is greatly influenced by the relative proportions of antigens and antibodies.

  • Prozone phenomenon is caused by excessive antibodies in the test system. (weak/absent precipitation- false-negative test)
  • Zone of equivalence- antigen, and antibody are in optimum proportions and maximum precipitation occurs.
  • Post–zone phenomenon is due to the presence of excessive antigen in the test system. (weaker/absent precipitation) 

 

Flocculation: Instead of sedimenting, precipitate remains suspended as floculus.

questions.text: A patient presents with a painless ulcer on his penis. A Wasserman test is done and is reactive. What is the principle of this test?
questions.solution:
Wassermann's reaction is an example of a complement fixation test. It is a non-specific test for the diagnosis of syphilis. 

An antigen combines with its (specific) antibody in the presence of complement, and the antigen-antibody complex adsorbs the complement. This reaction is not visible and requires the use of an indicator (sheep erythrocytes and the specific anti-erythrocyte antibody).

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not a cell mediated type of hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Casoni’s test is a type I hypersensitivity reaction used in the diagnosis of hydatid disease.

  • It involves the intradermal injection of 0.25 ml of sterilized fluid from hydatid cysts/human cyst and sterilized by Seitz filtration on the forearm and an equal volume of saline injected on the other forearm.
  • Observations are made for next 30 mins and after 1 to 2 days.
  • A wheal response occurring at the injection site within 20 minutes is considered positive.

Cell-mediated or type IV type of hypersensitivity reaction is a delayed hypersensitivity. 

In the tuberculin skin test, the indurated skin rash is caused by CD4-positive helper T cells and macrophages that are attracted to the injection site.

The Frei test is done to identify lymphogranuloma venereum. Antigen made from sterile pus aspirated from previously unruptured abscesses produced a reaction in patients with lymphogranuloma inguinale when injected intradermally.

Montenegro test is a delayed hypersensitivity test for cutaneous leishmaniasis.

questions.text: A skin transplant was done from a sister to her brother. After a few years, a brother-to-sister skin transplant was done, but rejection occurred. What is this phenomenon known as?
questions.solution:
The above scenario describes an Eichwald-Silmser effect, which is a unilateral sex-linked histo-incompatibility.

While transplants between same-sex siblings are successful, grafts from female to male are also successful, but an exception is seen when the donor is a male and the recipient is a female. Such grafts are rejected as the grafted male tissue (XY) will have antigens determined by the Y chromosome which will be absent in the female (XX) recipient.

questions.text: Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to the absence of _______
questions.solution:
Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to absence of T cell.

A xenograft is a tissue graft or organ transplant from a donor of a different species.

Nude mice lack body hair, hence the name. They lack a thymus and thus cannot generate mature T lymphocytes. The absence of T-lymphocytes makes them unable to mount adaptive immune responses requiring helper T cells and cytotoxic T cells. The absence of functioning T cells also prevents the rejection of allografts & xenografts.

questions.text: Macrophages are the major source of ______.
questions.solution:
Macrophages are the major source of IL-1.

Macrophages are phagocytic cells that secrete the following molecules: 

  • Enzymes - Lysozyme, proteases, elastases, collagenases, plasminogen activator.
  • Cytokines - Interleukins 1, 6, 8, 10, 12; TNF-α; TGF-β; prostaglandins.
  • Platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF), Platelet activated factor (PAF).
  • Colony-stimulating factor (CSF), Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE)
  • Complements - C2, C4.
  • Reactive O2 species (ROS)- H2O2, NO, OH.

Interferon-gamma (IFN-γ) is secreted by T-cells. It is one of the most potent macrophage activators.

Related Pearl: Cytokines

Interleukins Main sources
IL-1 (α and β) Macrophages and other cell types
IL-2 T cells
IL-3 T cells
IL-4 TH cells
IL-5 TH cells
IL-6 TH, macrophages, fibroblasts
IL-8 Macrophages, others
IL-10 T, B cells, macrophages

Pro-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-1: induces inﬂammation, fever, and sepsis, activates TNF-α; proliferation and differentiation of T, B, and other cells; bone marrow cell proliferation
  • IL-2: promote growth and differentiation of T and B cells; cytotoxicity of T and NK cells; secretion of other lymphokines
  • IL-6: promote B cell stimulation & differentiation; mediator of acute phase reactions; IgG production
  • IL-8: attracts and activates neutrophils in inflammatory regions; neutrophil chemotaxis
  • IFN-α: antiviral, immunoregulatory (enhance MHC class I, NK-cell activity), antiproliferative
  • TNF-α: activate macrophages and cytotoxic cells, induce cachexia, acute phase proteins, cytokines such as IL-1 and IL-6

Anti-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-4: proliferation of B and cytotoxic cells; increases IgG1 and IgE production; enhances MHC-class II receptor
  • IL-10: inhibits IFN-γ and IL-12 production; inhibits IFN production and mononuclear cell functions
  • IL-13

Acute inflammation and sepsis: 

  • TNF-α
  • IL-1

Special Cytokines: 

  1. IFN-γ: 
    • Granuloma formation
    • Antiviral
    • Immunoregulatory (enhances MHC classes I and II and macrophage activation)
    • Antiproliferative
  2. TGF-β: 
    • Fibrosis 
    • Activate macrophages
  3. VEGF:
    • promotes angiogenesis

questions.text: Which of the following mediators of inflammation is an example of a C-X-C chemokine?
questions.solution:
Interleukin-8 is an example of a C-X-C chemokine. 

Chemokines are chemotactic (chemoattractant) cytokines. They recruit leukocytes to sites of inflammation. The  C-X-C or alpha chemokines have a total of four cysteines, of which the first two separated by one amino acid.  represented by 'X'. 

Related Pearl: Various Types of Chemokines Based on their Structure

1.   CXC chemokines (α-chemokines): They have a total of four cysteines, of which the first two separated by one amino acid, represented by 'X'. e.g., interleukin-8 (IL-8/ CXCL8)

2. CC chemokines (β-chemokines): They have a total of four cysteines, of which the first two are adjacent near their amino terminus. e.g., CC chemokine ligands (CCL-1 to 28).

3. C chemokines (γ-chemokines): They have only two cysteines; the first and third of the four cysteines i.e. one N-terminal cysteine and one cysteine downstream. e.g., XCL1 (lymphotactin-α) and XCL2 (lymphotactin-β).

4. CX3C chemokines (d-chemokines): They have three amino acids between two cysteines e.g., fractalkine (or CX3CL1). It acts as a chemoattractant and as an adhesion molecule.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child has a history of recurrent skin and respiratory tract infections. Investigations are carried out and a disorder of phagocytosis is suspected. Which of the following will not be a differential diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
DiGeorge syndrome is not a disorder of phagocytosis.

It is due to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches. Cell-mediated immunity is defective due to decreased T-cells. Affected individuals also have depressed graft rejection, hypocalcemia, and cardiac defects. 

Disorders of phagocytosis:

  • Leukocyte adhesion deficiency
  • Chediak–Higashi syndrome
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia

Other options: 

Option B: Leukocyte adhesion deficiency leads to defective neutrophil migration to sites of infection, peripheral neutrophilia, and recurrent infections without pus.

Option C: Chediak–Higashi syndrome is an autosomal-recessive disorder due to defects in lysosomal transport protein (LYST), leading to defective microtubule polymerization and defective phagolysosome formation. There is neutropenia and recurrent infections. 

Option D: Chronic granulomatous disease is due to a defect in NADPH oxidase resulting in the absence of respiratory burst. It presents with recurrent infections with catalase-positive microbes.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

 

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

The image below shows the abnormal facies in DiGeorge syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following syndromes corresponds to a failure of neutrophils to generate an immune response and lab values indicate elevated IgE levels?
questions.solution:
Job’s Syndrome corresponds to a failure of neutrophils to generate an immune response and lab values indicate elevated IgE levels.

Hyperimmunoglobulinemia E syndrome - its autosomal dominant form is called Job's syndrome or Buckley syndrome.

  • It is a disorder of phagocytosis associated with elevated IgE levels.
  • This is characterized by multiple large staphylococcal ‘cold’ abscesses, which occur repeatedly on the skin containing large quantities of pus.
  • Atopic eczema, chronic nasal discharge, and otitis media are common features.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Humoral response is detrimental to host defense against malignancy. 
Reason (R): Cell-mediated immunity is believed to be the mechanism of host defense against malignancy.

choices.text: A is true, R is false
A is false, R is true
Both A and R are true, R is not the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, R is the correct explanation of A

questions.solution:
Humoral response is not relevant or may even be detrimental to host defense against malignancy. 

B cells respond to tumor-specific antigens by generating anti-tumor antibodies that can foster tumor-cell recognition and lysis. However, some anti-tumor antibodies serve a more detrimental role, blocking cytotoxic T lymphocytes access to tumor-specific antigens and enhancing survival of the cancerous cells. For this reason, a clear positive or negative role for B cells in cancer immunity is less obvious.

Cell-mediated immunity is believed to be the mechanism of host defence against malignancy.

questions.text: The specimen obtained by performing incision and drainage of a breast abscess was sent for culture on nutrient agar.  An image of the culture plate is given below. Microscopy of the isolated organism revealed gram-positive cocci arranged in clusters. Which of the following is a false statement regarding this organism?

choices.text: Golden yellow pigmentation  is due to β-carotene
Pigment production is enhanced by adding milk to culture media
Confluent growth presents a characteristic  'oil-paint appearance'

questions.solution:
Gram-positive cocci arranged in clusters that produce golden-yellow pigment on nutrient agar is suggestive of Staphylococcus aureus. The pigment production occurs optimally at 22°C.

Staphylococcus aureus is a Gram-positive coccus. On nutrient agar, its colonies are large (2-4 mm in diameter), convex, smooth, shiny, opaque and easily emulsifiable. The colonies appear golden yellow due to the presence of staphyloxanthin (carotenoid). Pigment production occurs optimally at 22°C and in aerobic conditions. It is enhanced when 1% glycerol or milk is incorporated in the medium.

On a nutrient agar slope, there is confluent growth of Staphylococcus, which appears as a characteristic oil-paint appearance.

questions.text: True about methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) is

choices.text: It is mediated by mecA gene
Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is of no use in diagnosis
Cephalosporins are the drug of choice
Panton-Valentine toxin is associated with HA-MRSA (hospital acquired MRSA)

questions.solution:
Resistance in methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus is mediated by mecA gene, which is chromosomally coded.

  • It alters penicillin-binding protein (PBP) present on S. aureus cell wall to PBP-2a, which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.
  • Panton-valentine toxin is associated with CA-MRSA (community-acquired MRSA)
  • Vancomycin is the drug of choice (should be used only if there is resistance to other drugs).
  • Drug of choice for nasal carriers of MRSA: mupirocin 2% ointment.

Related Pearl: Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

MRSA Definition: Methicillin MIC 8 μg/ml or more, Oxacillin MIC 4 μg/ml or more.

Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded. It alters PBP (penicillin-binding protein) present on S.aureus cell wall to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin Binding Protein:

  • Normal protein present in all bacterial cell wall.
  • Transpeptidase in nature.
  • Required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer (essential for cell wall synthesis).
  • It is also the site of attachment for- beta-lactam drugs to bind & inhibit.

Types of MRSA:

  • Community-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype IV and Possess PV Toxin(Panton-Valentine Toxin), monodrug resistance,more virulent
  • Hospital-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype I, II, III, multidrug resistance,less virulent.

Detection of MRSA:

  • Antibiotic susceptibility test on Muller Hilton agar (Disk diffusion test) by using Methicillin or Oxacillin disc or cefoxitin disc.
  • PCR for detection of mecA gene.

Treatment:

  • Vancomycin is Drug Of Choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • Others- Teicoplanin, Linezolid, streptogramin, cipro/levofloxacin, cotrimoxazole, clindamycin, mupirocin, minocycline.
  • Newer Drugs – Daptomycin, ceftobiprole, tigecycline, oritavancin, dalbavancin, telavancin, delafloxacin.
  • Ceftobiprole and ceftaroline are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

questions.text: A man presents with fever, chills and abdominal pain for 1 week. He underwent valve replacement for symptomatic aortic valve stenosis 4 months ago. On auscultation, an early diastolic murmur is noted along the lower left sternal margin which increases in intensity during the Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following statements is true about the most common organism causing this condition?
questions.solution:
Fever and chills with aortic regurgitation (an early diastolic murmur along the left sternal margin increasing in intensity during the Valsalva manoeuvre) in a patient with a prosthetic valve suggest a diagnosis of prosthetic valve left-sided infective endocarditis. The most common organism causing it within 12 months of surgery is coagulase-negative Staphylococci (CoNS). Its cell wall contains teichoic acid. 

Infective endocarditis is the microbial infection of heart valves or endocardium, leading to the formation of vegetations (thrombotic debris and microbial organisms). Patients present with fever, chills and heart murmurs. Non-cardiac manifestations like subungual hemorrhage, Osler's nodes and arteria emboli may be seen. The most common organism causing IE overall is Staphylococcus aureus. The most common organism causing prosthetic valve endocarditis within 12 months of surgery is coagulase-negative Staphylococci, like Staphylococcus epidermidis. 

Staphylococcus epidermidis is a Gram-positive coccus arranged in clusters. It is coagulase-negative (option B) and is resistant to lysostaphin (option D). It is non-hemolytic (option C). It is a part of normal flora of the human body.

The following image shows a graphical illustration of vegetations seen in infective endocarditis.

Related Pearl: Microbiology of Infective Endocarditis

 Condition

Most common organism

Most common organism overall

Staphylococcus aureus

Community-acquired native valve endocarditis

Streptococci

Healthcare-associated native valve endocarditis

Staphylococcus aureus
Endocarditis in injection drug users (Right side) Staphylococcus aureus
Endocarditis in injection drug users (Left side) Enterococci and Staphylococcus aureus

Single most common organism causing prosthetic valve endocarditis

Staphylococcus aureus

Most common group of organism causing early prosthetic valve endocarditis (<12 months after surgery)

 

Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS)*

Late prosthetic valve endocarditis (>12 months after surgery)

Streptococci

 

Acute infective endocarditis

Staphylococcus aureus

Subacute infective endocarditis

Streptococcus viridans

Enterococci

Coagulase-negative Staphylococci (CoNS)

HACEK

Cardiovascular implantable electronic device (CIED)-associated endocarditis

Staphylococcus aureus  and coagulase-negative Staphylococci (CoNS)*

Culture negative endocarditis

Prior antibiotic use

Nutritionally variant streptococci

HACEK organisms

Coxiella burnetii

Bartonella

NOTE :

*CoNS includes Staphylococcus epidermidis and other coagulase-negative types

*Streptococci includes Viridans streptococci (VGS), Streptococcus gallolyticus (previously Streptococcus bovis biotype 1) and other non-groupable and groupable streptococci

 

Microorganism

Source

Streptococcus viridans

Oral cavity

Staphylococcus aureus

Skin

HACEK organisms

Upper respiratory tract

Streptococcus gallolyticus

GIT (Colon )

Enterococci

Genitourinary tract

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presented with complaints of burning micturition and fever with chills for three days. Which of the following organisms is a common cause for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of burning micturition and fever with chills is suggestive of a urinary tract infection(UTI). Staphylococcus saprophyticus is the most common cause of UTI in young women among the given options.

Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a gram-positive, coagulase-negative staphylococcus. It is non-pigmented, novobiocin resistant and non-hemolytic on blood agar. It is a leading cause of cystitis in women.

Note: E. coli is the most common cause of UTI overall.

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement regarding Micrococci.

choices.text: It is rarely associated with disease.

questions.solution:
Micrococci are arranged in pairs, tetrads or clusters of eight. 

Micrococci are Gram-positive cocci that are often mistaken for S. aureus. However, they are larger in size and mostly occur in pairs, tetrads or clusters of eight. They form smaller colonies in culture in comparison to S. aureus. Hugh-Leifson oxidation-fermentation test can be used to differentiate between micrococci (oxidative pattern) and staphylococci (fermentative pattern).

Micrococci are catalase-positive and modified oxidase-positive. They are ordinarily non-pathogenic but can rarely cause infections in an immunocompromised host. They are part of normal bacterial flora in the body.

The following image shows the tetrad arrangement of micrococci:

Different bacteria with their typical arrangements are given below:

1. Staphylococcus: Clusters
2. Streptococcus: Chains
3. Pneumococcus: Pairs/lanceolate shaped
4. Micrococcus: Tetrads

questions.text: Which of the following organisms show beta-hemolysis on blood agar, resistance to bacitracin, and a positive CAMP test?
questions.solution:
Streptococcus agalactiae is a group B streptococci that shows β-hemolysis on blood agar, is resistant to bacitracin, and gives a positive CAMP test.

The CAMP test is used to identify group B β-hemolyitic-streptococci based on their ability to form CAMP factor. This factor causes synergistic hemolysis with β-hemolysin formed by Staphylococcus aureus, when Streptococcus agalactiae is inoculated perpendicular to a streak of Staphylococcus aureus on blood agar. This produces the characteristic arrow-head zone of hemolysis.

The below image shows a positive CAMP test. 

The following table provides important laboratory characteristics which differentiate Streptococcus pyogenes from Streptococcus agalactiae.

Species Lancefield Group Typical Hemolysis Important Lab Characteristics
S.pyogenes A β Bacitracin sensitive, PYR test positive
S.agalactiae B β Bacitracin resistant, PYR test negative, Hippurate hydrolysis positive, CAMP test positive

questions.text: Oral examination of a young patient shows the following finding. Which bacteria belonging to viridans group is most commonly implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows dental caries which are commonly caused by Streptococcus mutans. It belongs to the viridans group/α-hemolytic streptococci.

Streptococcus mutans breaks down the dietary sucrose producing acid and a tough adhesive dextran. The acid damages dentine while the dextrans bind together with food debris, epithelial cells, mucus, and bacteria to form dental plaques, leading to formation of dental caries.

Related Pearl: Differentiation between Streptococcus pneumoniae and Streptococcus viridans

Characteristics Streptococcus pneumoniae Streptococcus viridans
Morphology Lanceolate diplococci Cocci in chains
Capsule Capsulated Non-capsulated
Quellung Test Positive Negative
Colonies Initially Dome Shaped, Later Draughtsman Colonies Dome shaped
Growth in Liquid Media Uniform Turbidity Granular Turbidity, powdery deposit
Bile solubility Bile soluble Bile insoluble
Inulin fermentation Positive Negative
Optochin sensitivity Sensitive Resistant
Intraperitoneal inoculation in Mice Fatal infection Non-pathogenic
Hemolysis Alpha-hemolytic (under aerobic conditions) or Beta-hemolytic (under anaerobic conditions) Alpha hemolytic or non-hemolytic

questions.text: A patient presented with bull neck edema and a pseudomembrane on the tonsils. Which of the following stains is used to demonstrate volutin granules of this organism?
questions.solution:
Presence of bull neck edema and pseudomembrane on tonsils points towards the diagnosis of diphtheria. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Albert stain is one of three stains that can be used to demonstrate the volutin granules (metachromatic/Babes-Ernst granules) of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. 

The two other stains used for this purpose are Neisser’s stain and Ponder’s stain. The bacilli are usually arranged in pairs or palisades or small groups, at various angles to each other, resembling the letters V or L. This has been called the Chinese letter or cuneiform arrangement.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in Pathology and Microbiology

Staining technique Cells/inclusions stained Disorders
H&E Most common stain used in routine histopathology Commonly used for all slides
Papanicolaou stain Universal stain for cytological preparations Cytological studies
PAS Demonstrate glycogen, mucin, fungi, macrophages  Whipple's disease, adenocarcinomas, and glycogen-positive tumors (Ewings sarcoma, renal cell carcinoma)
PTAH (Phosphotungstic acid hematoxylin) Fibrin Gliosis, Ependymomas, Tumours of skeletal muscles, Fibrin deposits
Alcian blue For acid mucins: Positive stain for mucins of the intestinal mucosa and negative stain for mucins of gastric mucosa and Brunner's gland Barrett's esophagus, Gastric disorders
Perl's Prussian blue Demonstrate hemosiderin and iron Hemochromatosis 
Masson–Fontana stain Demonstrate melanin Nevus and malignant melanoma
von Kossa method Demonstrate calcium Calcification of tissues
Van Gieson stain

Demonstrate collagen in; Differentiate amyloid from collagen

 Spindle-cell neoplasm; Delineate extent of fibrosis 
Masson trichrome stain Demonstrate collagen and muscle Connective tissue disorders, muscle and fibroblast tumors, liver cirrhosis, neuromuscular diseases 
Reticulin stain Demonstrate reticulin fibers Distinguish epithelial from non-epithelial neoplasm, Hodgkin's lymphoma, early cirrhosis of the liver, myelofibrosis
Verhoeff's method Demonstrate elastic fibers Malignant hypertension, arteriovenous malformation aneurysms, Marfan's syndrome, emphysema lung
Oil red O Sudan Black Sudan III/IV Demonstrate fat/lipids Fatty liver-fat embolism-fibroma vs. thecoma of the ovary-liposarcoma 

Microbiology stains:

Stain  Uses
Ziehl–Neelsen Stain Mycobacteria (all species, including Mycobacterium leprae), Nocardia spp. Cyst of Cryptosporidium parvum, Isospora spp., and Cyclospora spp., Head of sperms
Masson’s Fontana Melanin and argentaffin Cells
Gomori Methenamine Silver Fungi
Luxol Fast Blue (LFB) Myelin
Phosphotungstic Acid-hematoxylin Cross striations of skeletal muscle, fibrin
Toluidine blue Mast cells
Warthin–Starry Helicobacter pylori, spirochetes
Van Gieson Collagen fibres
Mucicarmine Mucin, Cryptococcus capsule

questions.text: Macleod's classification of diphtheria bacilli into gravis, intermedius, and mitis is based on

choices.text: Colony morphology on Tellurite blood Agar

questions.solution:
Macleod's classification of diphtheria bacilli into gravis, intermedius, and mitis is based on colony morphology on tellurite blood agar.

Tellurite blood agar is a selective medium for the culture of diphtheria bacilli.

The diphtheria bacilli reduced tellurite to metallic tellurium, which is incorporated in the colonies, giving them a grey or black color.

The growth of diphtheria bacilli may be delayed on the tellurite medium and colonies may take two days to appear.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male presented with the following finding in his axilla. On wood's lamp examination, a characteristic coral pink fluorescence was seen. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given image showing hyperpigmented lesion in axilla along with the coral red fluorescence seen under wood's lamp is suggestive of erythrasma. This condition is caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum which is usually present as a normal human skin inhabitant.

Erythrasma is a chronic superficial infection of the intertriginous areas (axilla, anogenital regions, skin folds of breast, etc.) of the skin. The coral-red fluorescence of scales seen under wood's lamp is secondary to the production of porphyrin by the diphtheroids.

questions.text: A 45-year-old fisherman presents with pain and a lesion in his hand similar to what is shown in the image.  What is the causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a raised, well-circumscribed, violaceous lesion with the absence of pus. Thus, it is erysipeloid which is a skin infection caused by Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae.

Erysipeloid usually occurs on the fingers by direct inoculation at the site of a cut or abrasion, in people who handle animals, fish or animal products. Pain, swelling and erythema develop and the condition has been called seal finger and whale finger. Pus is usually absent at the infection site, which helps differentiate it from staphylococcal and streptococcal skin infections. It resolves without treatment in 3-4 weeks. 

Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae is a slender, non-motile, non-sporing Gram positive bacillus. It is catalase, oxidase, and indole negative. It causes disease in multiple land animals like swine, turkeys and sheep. 

Note: Erysipelas is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. It presents as erythematous raised lesions with sharply demarcated edges.

questions.text: The following colony morphology is characteristic of
questions.solution:
The given image shows characteristic molar tooth colonies of Actinomyces species.

They are seen after 72 hours growth on brain-heart infusion agar.

Related Pearl: Differences between Eumycetoma and Actinomycetoma

Feature

Eumycetoma

Actinomycetoma

Etiology

Filamentous fungi

Fungus-like bacteria

Grains

Madurella mycetomatis and grisia- black grains

 Actinomadura madurae and Nocardia asteroids- white-yellow grains

Progression

Slow

Rapid
Sites of involvement

 

Feet and hands

Involvement of covered parts

Swelling

Well circumscribed and marked in the later stage

Ill-defined and merges with surrounding tissue

Tissue destruction

Marked in the later stage

Involvement of bone is earlier and extensive

Filaments

Wide (2–5

μm) and septate hyphae, Periodic Schiff (PAS) positive and gram-negative easily visualized at ×400

Slender (0.5–

μm) and nonseptate, PAS negative and gram-positive filaments difficult to visualize even at ×800

Response to treatment

Unresponsive and requires surgical debulking

Good response

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Nocardiosis?

choices.text: Person to person spread is seen
It is seen more commonly during the summer
N. asteroides is the most commonly involved Nocardia species in human disease
The organism is sensitive to penicillin

questions.solution:
Nocardia asteroides is most commonly involved Nocardia species in human disease.

  • The organism is resistant to penicillin; hence, cotrimoxazole is mainly used for treatment.
  • Transmission occurs through inhalation contaminated soil not from animals or infected humans.
  • No seasonal variation is seen.

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding the pathogenesis of listeriosis.

choices.text: The bacterium adheres to the microvilli  & disrupts the cell membrane causing diarrhoea.
Listeriolysin  O lyses the cell membrane & allows the Listeriae to move freely from cell-to-cell.
Listeria moves from cell-to-cell using host cell actin framework.
Listeria forms elongated protrusions against the host cell membrane called pseudopods; which help in its spread to distant sites.

questions.solution:
Listeria moves from cell-to-cell using host cell actin framework.

  • Listeria monocytogenes enters the body through the GIT after ingestion of contaminated food such as cheese or vegetables.
  • It has two cell-surface proteins, internalins A and B, which interact with the epithelial E-cadherin and promote its own phagocytosis into the gut epithelial cells.
  • In the phagolysosome, the low pH activates the bacterium to produce listeriolysin O.
  • This enzyme lyses the membrane of the phagolysosome and allows Listeria to escape into the cytoplasm of the epithelial cell.
  • Here, the organisms proliferate and produce ActA, a listerial protein which induces host cell actin polymerization.
  • This process propels them to the host cell membrane.
  • Pushing against the host cell membrane, they cause the formation of elongated protrusions called filopods.
  • These filopods are ingested by adjacent epithelial cells, macrophages, and hepatocytes, the listeriae are released & the cycle begins again.
  • In this way, Listeria moves from cell-to-cell using host actin framework without being exposed to antibodies, complement system, or neutrophils.

questions.text: A young man presented with complaints of severe abdominal pain and watery diarrhoea eight hours after consuming meat at a restaurant.  A stool sample was sent for culture and the isolated organism showed this appearance on litmus milk fermentation. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the image showing stormy fermentation of lactose in litmus milk is suggestive of gastroenteritis caused by Clostridium perfingens type A.

The fermentation of lactose by this organism leads to the formation of acid which coagulates the casein in litmus milk. The clotted milk is disrupted due to vigorous gas production and this characteristic finding is obtained that is called stormy fermentation.

questions.text: The following statements are true regarding botulism except

choices.text: Infant botulism is caused by ingestion of preformed toxin
Clostridium botulinum toxins A,B,E and F cause human disease
The gene for botulinum toxin is chromosomal mediated

questions.solution:
Infant botulism occurs due to the ingestion of spores, not a preformed toxin. The toxin is released inside the body.

Food-borne botulism occurs due to preformed toxin mixed with canned food.

Other options: 

Option b:  Clostridium botulinum Toxin types A, B, E, and (rarely) F cause disease in humans.  Although type G has not been known to cause any disease in humans, few reports of sudden deaths have been recorded. Type C and D cause disease in animals.
Option c: Botulinum toxins can be chromosomally mediated, plasmid-mediated or phage mediated.
Option d: Rare strains of other clostridia species such as Clostridium butyricum and Clostridium baratii, have been found to cause botulism.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms form the citron bodies?
questions.solution:
Citron bodies are boat or leaf-shaped pleomorphic bacteria, usually associated with Clostridium septicum. 

It is a gram-positive, spore-forming, obligate anaerobic bacterium.

Gram stain morphology of Clostridium septicum from CSF (a) and blood culture (b) in 1000× magnification with spore formation(arrow) is shown below.

questions.text: Which of the following bacilli characteristically shows the M’Fadyean’s reaction?
questions.solution:
M'Fadyean’s reaction is shown by Bacillus anthracis.

When a blood film containing anthrax bacilli is stained with polychrome methylene blue for a few seconds and examined under the microscope, amorphous purplish material is noticed around the bacilli. This represents the capsular material and is called M'Fadyean’s reaction.

The following micrograph shows M'Fadyean's reaction:

questions.text: Which of the following bacilli is used to test the efficacy of sterilisation by autoclave?
questions.solution:
Geobacillus stearothermophilus (formerly Bacillus stearothermophilus) is used to test the efficacy of sterilization by autoclave.

Option A: Bacillus atrophaeus (Bacillus subtilis) & Geobacillus stearothermophilus, are both used to test the efficacy of plasma sterilization.

Option B: Bacillus pumilus is used as the control for sterilisation using ionizing radiation.

Option D: Bacillus globigii is used as the control for sterilisation using ethylene oxide.

questions.text: A swab was taken from an ulcer and sent to the laboratory for culture. The following image depicts a blood agar culture plate on which gamma phage suspension has been applied. Which of the following is the most likely organism implicated?
questions.solution:
The given image with a circular spot of diminished growth in the culture plate from a swab from an ulcer depicts the gamma phage lysis assay. The most likely organism implicated is Bacillus Anthracis.

This test is performed by inoculating Bacillus Anthracis in sheep blood agar followed by the application of gamma phage suspension over one area of the culture plate. The gamma phage suspension inhibits the growth of Bacillus anthracis colonies resulting in an an area of diminished growth called a plaque.
